extendedIngredients.name: cream sherry
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tablespoons mirin, or cream sherry (see Note)

extendedIngredients.name: low sodium chicken broth
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3/4 cup fish stock, or reduced-sodium chicken broth

extendedIngredients.name: Salt & Pepper
extendedIngredients.originalString: Salt & freshly ground pepper, to taste

extendedIngredients.name: shrimp
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 1/2 pounds medium shrimp, peeled and deveined

extendedIngredients.name: vine ripened tomatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 large vine-ripened tomatoes, seeded and chopped

recipes.title: Saucy Gingered Shrimp with Zucchini & Red Peppers

winePairing.pairingText: Fish works really well with Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Grüner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Tiamo Pinot Grigio with a 4.2 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 8 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Tiamo Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description: Light straw yellow color. Fresh and rich fruity aromas of apple and pear with a hint of citrus fruit that fade into the floral bouquet. Fresh and fruity, very clean and crisp.Tiamo Pinot Grigio pairs well with a wide array of lighter cuisine, especially fish/shellfish, poultry, pastas in cream sauce and softer cheeses. It's also an ideal aperitif.

recipes.instructions: Heat 1 1/2 teaspoons oil in a large cast-iron or nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add bell pepper and zucchini; cook until barely tender, about 2 minutes. Transfer to a dish and reserve.Add 1 tablespoon oil to the pan and increase heat to medium-high. When oil is hot but not smoking, add shrimp and jalapeo; saut until the shrimp are nicely browned, 1 to 3 minutes. Transfer to a dish and set aside.Add the remaining 1 1/2 teaspoons oil to the pan, then add shallot, ginger and garlic; saut until the mixture is soft but not brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Pour in wine and lime juice; boil until reduced to a glaze, 3 to 5 minutes. Pour in stock (or broth) and mirin (or sherry); boil until reduced to 2 tablespoons, about 5 minutes. Add tomatoes, season with salt and pepper, and simmer for 2 to 3 minutes.Dissolve cornstarch in water in a small bowl; whisk into simmering mixture and cook, stirring, until the sauce thickens slightly, about 1 minute. Reduce heat to low, add scallions, cilantro, the reserved vegetable mixture and shrimp (with their juices) to the pan and just heat through. Season with salt and pepper.

steps.step: Heat 1 1/2 teaspoons oil in a large cast-iron or nonstick skillet over medium heat.
Add bell pepper and zucchini; cook until barely tender, about 2 minutes.
Transfer to a dish and reserve.
Add 1 tablespoon oil to the pan and increase heat to medium-high. When oil is hot but not smoking, add shrimp and jalapeo; saut until the shrimp are nicely browned, 1 to 3 minutes.
Transfer to a dish and set aside.
Add the remaining 1 1/2 teaspoons oil to the pan, then add shallot, ginger and garlic; saut until the mixture is soft but not brown, 1 to 2 minutes.
Pour in wine and lime juice; boil until reduced to a glaze, 3 to 5 minutes.
Pour in stock (or broth) and mirin (or sherry); boil until reduced to 2 tablespoons, about 5 minutes.

Add tomatoes, season with salt and pepper, and simmer for 2 to 3 minutes.Dissolve cornstarch in water in a small bowl; whisk into simmering mixture and cook, stirring, until the sauce thickens slightly, about 1 minute. Reduce heat to low, add scallions, cilantro, the reserved vegetable mixture and shrimp (with their juices) to the pan and just heat through. Season with salt and pepper.
